main_post:
We built reactors that could run for decades on aircraft carriers. Zero meltdowns. Zero excuses.

Yet civilian SMRs face 10+ years of NRC paper-pushing for designs wealready know work.

The nuclear navy proved safety through engineering. The NRC demands safety through documentation.

Which method kept sailors alive?

#NuclearEnergy #SMRs #MoltenSalt #EnergyPolicy

thread.content:
I spent years in the Navy's nuclear program. We operated reactors with 95%+ uptime, surrounded by ocean, in combat conditions, with 20-year-old sailors at the controls.

Not a single meltdown in 70+ years. Not one.

So why does a land-based SMR need a decade of regulatory review?

The nuclear navy worked because we prioritized:

✓ Passive safety systems
✓ Rigorous training
✓ Proven designs iterated over decades

The NRC demands:
✓ Thousands of pages of environmental impact statements
✓ Site-specific licensing for identical designs
✓ Political approval disguised as engineering review

NuScale spent $500M+ and 10 years getting their first SMR design approved.

Then the project in Idaho got canceled because costs ballooned and utilities lost patience.

We didn't lose SMRs to engineering problems. We lost them to process problems.

Meanwhile, China has their first SMR online right now. Russia been running floating SMRs since 2019.

We're falling behind not because we can't build reactors—we built the best ones in the world.

We're falling behind because we forgot how to let people build.

People misunderstand SMRs. We're not talking about experimental technology.

These are scaled-down versions of proven designs with passive safety features that work without power, without operators, without anything.

Physics doesn't change just because the reactor's smaller.

The real opportunity? Molten salt reactors running on thorium.

Can't melt down (already liquid). Can't produce weapons-grade material efficiently. Uses 99% of fuel vs ~1% for solid fuel reactors.

Kirk Sorensen has been banging this drum for 20 years. We should be building them already.

The waste argument is pure theater.

France recycles nuclear waste. The total volume from decades of their program fits in one building.

Compare that to coal ash—radioactive, toxic, millions of tons annually—and tell me which needs more regulatory attention.

Here's what reform could look like:

1. Generic design certification that applies nationwide
2. Streamlined approval for proven reactor types
3. Pre-approved sites for rapid deployment
4. International reciprocity—if Canada/EU approved it, fast-track here

We're facing a trilemma: energy security, climate goals, and geopolitical competition.

SMRs solve all three. Small enough to deploy anywhere. Clean baseload power. Made in America (if we let ourselves build them).

The tech works. The will doesn't.

Nuclear trained me to think in systems. Every delay has cascading effects.

Every year we wait on SMRs:
→ More coal plants stay online
→ More dependency on Chinese solar manufacturing
→ More grid instability as renewables fluctuate

The cost of inaction compounds.

We need a licensing framework that matches the urgency of our challenges.

The Apollo program went from Kennedy's speech to boots on the moon in 8 years.

We've been talking about SMRs since the 1990s. What happened to American industrial capability?

If you believe climate change is an emergency, you should be angry about how we treat nuclear energy.

The cleanest, densest, most reliable source of power—and we smother it in red tape while celebrating intermittent alternatives.

Something doesn't add up.

target_audience: Policy makers, energy professionals, nuclear advocates
tone: Technical expertise + policy frustration + patriotic industrial concern
